Article Title: 'Irresponsible, dangerous': FDA memo links Covid shots to children deaths; proposes new vaccine rules
Article Text:
Representative image (Photo credit: ANI)





Director of the FDA’s Center for Biologics Evaluation and Research, Dr Vinay Prasad , told agency staff in a memo that at least ten children died ‘after and because of receiving’ the Covid-19 vaccine.The 3,000-word memo, obtained by NBC News, was authored by Dr Vinay Prasad, director of the FDA’s Center for Biologics Evaluation and Research. It claims that agency staff determined “no fewer than 10” of 96 child deaths reported to the Vaccine Adverse Event Reporting System (VAERS) between 2021 and 2024 were linked to Covid vaccines. Prasad suggested myocarditis, an inflammation of the heart muscle, as a possible cause but provided no supporting evidence."For the first time, the US FDA will acknowledge that COVID-19 vaccines have killed American children. Healthy young children who faced tremendously low risk of death were coerced, at the behest of the Biden administration, via school and work mandates, to receive a vaccine that could result in death. In many cases, such mandates were harmful. It is difficult to read cases where kids aged 7 to 16 may be dead as a result of covid vaccines", he wrote.The memo did not detail the children’s ages, medical histories, timelines, or the vaccine manufacturer, and the findings have not been peer-reviewed.Dr Paul Offit, a paediatrician and director of the Vaccine Education Center at the Children’s Hospital of Philadelphia, told NBC News: “This is sort of science by press release,” calling the memo “irresponsible” and “dangerous.”Dr Peter Marks, former FDA vaccine chief, criticised the agency’s handling of the data, saying the claims were drawn from what he described as the “anti-vaccine playbook.” Marks told The Guardian that the memo’s “clearly political tone” was alarming and noted that establishing causation in child deaths is complex. He added that VAERS is intended to detect early safety signals, not to confirm vaccine-related deaths.Dr Kathryn Edwards, professor emeritus at Vanderbilt University, said determining whether a vaccine caused death requires autopsies and careful review of other causes. She stressed that Covid itself has caused far more child deaths than those cited in the memo.Prasad’s memo also proposes sweeping changes to FDA vaccine evaluation, including revisiting flu shot assessments, requiring post-market proof of pneumonia vaccine effectiveness, and reconsidering co-administration of multiple vaccines. Experts warn these changes could slow approvals, delay product launches, and disrupt established immunisation schedules.The memo comes after the FDA and CDC limited Covid vaccine eligibility this winter to adults over 65 and those with underlying medical conditions.Previous research supports vaccine safety: a 2023 JAMA Pediatrics study of over 10 million children aged 5–11 found vaccination reduced infection and hospitalisation risk, while a 2024 Nature Communications study reported no rise in serious adverse events, noting only a very small risk of myocarditis in teen boys.

Article Title: ‘Six militants stormed base’: Suicide blast hits paramilitary HQ in Pakistan; three killed
Article Text:
(Photo credit: AP)

Pakistan Army General Warns Of Hybrid-To-Full War As Pakistan Reshapes Military Power Under Munir





Fresh violence broke out in Pakistan after a suicide bomber detonated himself at the main gate of the Frontier Corps (FC) headquarters in Nokkundi, Balochistan, sparking an intense exchange of fire and a major security response, Dawn reported.The attack, claimed to be the work of militants described by officials as Fitna-al-Khawarij — the state’s term for the banned Tehreek-i-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) — triggered a swift retaliatory operation in which three attackers were killed.According to FC Balochistan South, the assault began when a suicide bomber blew himself up at the entrance, allowing several armed militants to force their way into the compound. Security personnel from the quick response force immediately engaged the attackers, with heavy gunfire reported from the area. Officials said at least six gunmen were believed to have entered the headquarters, prompting a full-scale clearance operation that continued through the day.In a statement, the FC spokesperson said troops were determined to neutralise the remaining threat, adding that the “last of the terrorists will also be” dealt with.Local reports described sustained firing inside the headquarters as forces worked room-to-room to secure the facility.The incident comes just days after a similar assault on an FC compound in the northwestern city of Peshawar, where gunmen and two suicide bombers stormed a paramilitary headquarters, killing three people. Police had said the first bomber detonated at the main entrance while the second entered the compound, forcing law enforcement to cordon off the busy FC Chowk area amid multiple explosions.These attacks form part of a broader escalation in militant violence this year. Earlier attacks in Quetta — including a deadly car bomb outside a paramilitary base and a suicide blast at a political rally — have added to growing instability in Balochistan. The province has endured a long-running insurgency, with hundreds of security personnel killed in 2024 alone, alongside attacks claimed by separatist groups such as the Baloch Liberation Army.

Article Title: Balochistan: 7 blasts over 24 hours rock Pakistan’s southwest province; insurgents target multiple sites sparking widespread fear
Article Text:
file photo

Pakistan Army General Warns Of Hybrid-To-Full War As Pakistan Reshapes Military Power Under Munir





At least seven explosions were reported in Pakistan’s Balochistan province over the past 24 hours, with suspected insurgents targeting sites in Quetta and Dera Murad Jamali. No casualties were reported, although two security guards with a construction company were injured in the attacks.The incidents triggered fear and panic in the provincial capital.On Saturday, insurgents hurled hand grenades at a police checkpoint in Quetta, followed by the detonation of an IED near an Anti-Terrorism Department vehicle. Three additional explosions took place later in the evening, as cited by PTI.Senior Superintendent of Police Asif Khan said the blast near Lohr Karez, on the outskirts of Quetta, damaged the main line connecting the city with other parts of the country.SSP Khan said the attackers had planted IEDs on a railway track and detonated them as a train was scheduled to arrive at Quetta station. The blast damaged the track and forced the suspension of rail services.Khan added that armed men also attacked a construction company site on Quetta’s Sariab Road with hand grenades, damaging machinery and injuring two security guards. In another incident, motorcycle-borne insurgents hurled two hand grenades at the Manzoor Shaheed police station, one of which exploded while the other was defused by a bomb disposal squad.In Dera Murad Jamali, a patrolling police vehicle was targeted with hand grenades.Attackers also threw hand grenades in the Kech Beg area near a police patrol post in Quetta.No group immediately claimed responsibility for Saturday’s attacks, but insurgent activity resumed on Sunday morning.Earlier this year, at least ten people were killed and several others injured when a powerful car bomb exploded outside the paramilitary headquarters in Quetta.On September 3, a suicide bombing at a political rally in the city killed 11 people and wounded more than 40, targeting a stadium parking area where hundreds of Balochistan National Party supporters had gathered.Pakistani forces continue to battle a longstanding insurgency in Balochistan, which has claimed 782 lives in 2024. In March, the Baloch Liberation Army hijacked a train and killed off-duty troops.
